section.para: This example is dedicated to illustrate the usage of mindc++.

chapter.title: Overview

section.para: This overview shows the global example architecture. An UML component diagram (internal block diagram) has naturally been used in order to have a "component" representation.
Primitive and composite components are represented by red blocks. Provides interfaces are represented by lollipops connectors. Required interfaces are represented by sockets connectors.
The small square at the connector base represents the port. A port can be an implementation language like "ANSI C", "C++" , a protocol like "DPWS", "modbus" or a physical link like RS485, USB.
In our case the port represents always the "C" implementation language.
The anonymous component is an in-lined component in the zigBeeStack composite. This anonymous component aims to implement the zigBeeStack composite interface. This anonymous definition
has been temporary replaced by a "classic" primitive in the code (not in diagrams) because there's an incompatibility with the documentation generator.
Connections between the composite "external interfaces" and "internal interfaces" are performed by the delegation connection.

para.note: This overview as been realized by Artisan Studio (Atego).
The UML stereotype "anonymous" has been created.

chapter.title: Running the example in command line
chapter.para: In order to build this example please set the appropriate environment variable to the mindc++ compiler.
The root folder contains a Makefile. Please invoke "make" in order to build the example.
The build result is available in the target/Default/binary folder.
This build folder contains generated files, object files and the final binary

note.para: The Makefile invoke the mindc compiler with the following options: --cpp --flatten

para.code: These options are defined in the "Default.properties" file.

section.para: The MIND C++ model generates code following the MIND C++ model. This model allows the user to "code" components as hpp file (for the definition) and C++ file (for the implementation).
The user defines interfaces in the "itf" files
The user defines provided and required interfaces and connections between component in adl files.
The mindc++ compiler will generate all necessary C++ classes in order to support the following MIND features (cf. 2).
In order to illustrate the MIND C++ model, the C++ representation of the "temperatureCluster" component has been selected.
This diagram shows all classes (generated and user classes) related to the "temperatureCluster" component.
The relation of inheritance between the generated and user classes are shown.

example.title: Class diagram related to the "temperatureCluster" component.

section.para: The generated code follows the MIND C++ model.
This C++ model implements the following features:

row.entry: The temperatureSensor primitive extend the sensor type. Currently the model does not maintain the hierarchy; the parent component is merged with the child component.
The zigBeeStack component is a composite. This composite requires a led driver and a Flash driver and provides the ZigBee stack API.

The zigBeeStackAPI component is anonymous. The role of this in-lined component is to compose the ZigBee stack API. Note that the anonymous definition has been temporary replaced by a classic primitive component in the code.

section.para: The MIND C++ model allow the user to code his own CPP and HPP files.
The CPP file contains interface methods implementations and the HPP file contains the component definition (with private data and private methods).
The both next examples illustrate the CPP part of the "temperatureCluster" component.
